title: Creating a default Single View Application

To develop an application for iOS, you should start with an application called Xcode. There are other alternative tools you can use, but Xcode is Apple’s official tool. Note, however, that it only runs on macOS. The latest official version is Xcode 8.3.3 with Xcode 9 (currently in beta) due to be released later this year.

inline_content.Text: To develop an application for iOS, you should start with an application called Xcode. There are other alternative tools you can use, but Xcode is Apple’s official tool. Note, however, that it only runs on macOS. The latest official version is Xcode 8.3.3 with Xcode 9 (currently in beta) due to be released later this year.

title: Boot up your Mac and install
Xcode from the App Store
a
https://itunes.apple.com/in/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12
if it’s not already installed.

inline_content.Text: Boot up your Mac and install
Xcode from the App Store
if it’s not already installed.

title: (If you prefer not to use the App Store or have problems, you can also
download Xcode from the Apple Developer website
a
https://developer.apple.com/download/
, but make sure that you select the latest release version and
not
b
a beta version.)

inline_content.Text: (If you prefer not to use the App Store or have problems, you can also
download Xcode from the Apple Developer website
, but make sure that you select the latest release version and
not
a beta version.)

title: Open Xcode. The following window will open:

inline_content.Text: Open Xcode. The following window will open:

title: The window presents you with the following options:

inline_content.Text: The window presents you with the following options:

title: Getting started with a playground:
b

This was introduced with the Swift language and Xcode 6. It’s an interactive area which can be used to write small pieces of code to check runtime changes. It’s a great way for Swift learners to be introduced to new Swift features.

inline_content.Text: Getting started with a playground:

This was introduced with the Swift language and Xcode 6. It’s an interactive area which can be used to write small pieces of code to check runtime changes. It’s a great way for Swift learners to be introduced to new Swift features.

title: Create a new Xcode project:
b
Choose this option
i
, which creates a new project with default configuration.

inline_content.Text: Create a new Xcode project:
Choose this option
, which creates a new project with default configuration.

title: Check out an existing project:
b
This is used to check out a project from a repository location, for example, check out a project from SVN.

inline_content.Text: Check out an existing project:
This is used to check out a project from a repository location, for example, check out a project from SVN.

title: Select the second option
Create a new Xcode project
b
and Xcode will ask you to do some initial project setup:

inline_content.Text: Select the second option
Create a new Xcode project
and Xcode will ask you to do some initial project setup:

title: This wizard is used to select your project template. There are 5 options:

inline_content.Text: This wizard is used to select your project template. There are 5 options:

title: iOS:
b
Used to create iOS apps, libraries and frameworks

inline_content.Text: iOS:
Used to create iOS apps, libraries and frameworks

title: watchOS:
b
Used to create watchOS apps, libraries and frameworks

inline_content.Text: watchOS:
Used to create watchOS apps, libraries and frameworks

title: tvOS:
b
Used to create tvOS apps, libraries and frameworks

inline_content.Text: tvOS:
Used to create tvOS apps, libraries and frameworks

title: macOS:
b
Used to create macOS apps, libraries, frameworks, packages, AppleScripts, etc.

inline_content.Text: macOS:
Used to create macOS apps, libraries, frameworks, packages, AppleScripts, etc.

title: Cross-platform:
b
Used to create cross-platform apps, templates and In-App Purchase Contents

inline_content.Text: Cross-platform:
Used to create cross-platform apps, templates and In-App Purchase Contents

title: You can see that there are many different templates for your application. These templates are helpful to boost your development; they are pre-built with some basic project setups like UI interfaces and class files.

inline_content.Text: You can see that there are many different templates for your application. These templates are helpful to boost your development; they are pre-built with some basic project setups like UI interfaces and class files.

title: Here, we’ll use the first option,
iOS
b

inline_content.Text: Here, we’ll use the first option,
iOS
Master-Detail Application:

title: This template contains a combined master and detail interface: the master contains objects which are related to the detail interface. Selecting objects in the master will change the details interface. You can see this kind UI in the Settings, Notes and Contacts applications on the iPad.

inline_content.Text: This template contains a combined master and detail interface: the master contains objects which are related to the detail interface. Selecting objects in the master will change the details interface. You can see this kind UI in the Settings, Notes and Contacts applications on the iPad.
Page-Based Application:

title: This template is used to create the page-based application. Pages are different views held by one container.

inline_content.Text: This template is used to create the page-based application. Pages are different views held by one container.
Single View Application:

title: This is a normal application development template. This is good for beginners to learn application flow.

inline_content.Text: This is a normal application development template. This is good for beginners to learn application flow.
Tabbed Application:

title: This template creates tabs at the bottom part of an application. Each tab has a different UI and a different navigation flow. You can see this template used in apps like Clock, iTunes Store, iBooks and App Store.

inline_content.Text: This template creates tabs at the bottom part of an application. Each tab has a different UI and a different navigation flow. You can see this template used in apps like Clock, iTunes Store, iBooks and App Store.
Game:

title: This is a starting point for game development. You can go further with game technologies like SceneKit, SpriteKit, OpenGL ES and Metal.

inline_content.Text: This is a starting point for game development. You can go further with game technologies like SceneKit, SpriteKit, OpenGL ES and Metal.

title: In this example, we will start with
Single View Application
b

inline_content.Text: In this example, we will start with
Single View Application

title: The wizard helps you to define project properties:

inline_content.Text: The wizard helps you to define project properties:

title: Product Name:
b
The name of the project / application

inline_content.Text: Product Name:
The name of the project / application

title: Organization Name:
b
The name of the organization in which you are involved

inline_content.Text: Organization Name:
The name of the organization in which you are involved

title: Organization Identifier:
b
The unique organization identifier which is used in the bundle identifier. It is recommended to follow reverse domain name service notation.

inline_content.Text: Organization Identifier:
The unique organization identifier which is used in the bundle identifier. It is recommended to follow reverse domain name service notation.

title: Bundle Identifier:
b
This field is very important.
i

It is based on your project name and organization identifier, choose wisely. The bundle identifier will be used in the future to install the application on a device and upload the app to iTunes Connect (which is the place we upload apps to be published on the App Store). It’s a unique key to identify your application.

inline_content.Text: Bundle Identifier:
This field is very important.

It is based on your project name and organization identifier, choose wisely. The bundle identifier will be used in the future to install the application on a device and upload the app to iTunes Connect (which is the place we upload apps to be published on the App Store). It’s a unique key to identify your application.

title: Language:
b
The programming language which you would like to use. Here you can change Objective-C to Swift if it’s not selected.

inline_content.Text: Language:
The programming language which you would like to use. Here you can change Objective-C to Swift if it’s not selected.

title: Devices:
b

Supported devices for your application that can be changed later. It shows iPhone, iPad, and Universal. Universal applications support iPhone and iPad devices, and it’s recommended to select this option when it’s not necessary to run the app on only one kind of device.

inline_content.Text: Devices:

Supported devices for your application that can be changed later. It shows iPhone, iPad, and Universal. Universal applications support iPhone and iPad devices, and it’s recommended to select this option when it’s not necessary to run the app on only one kind of device.

title: Use Core Data:
b
If you would like to use Core Data Model in your project then mark it as selected, and it will create a file for the
.xcdatamodel
c
. You can also add this file later on if you don’t know in advance.

inline_content.Text: Use Core Data:
If you would like to use Core Data Model in your project then mark it as selected, and it will create a file for the
.xcdatamodel
. You can also add this file later on if you don’t know in advance.

title: Include Unit Tests:
b
This configures the unit test target and creates classes for unit testing

inline_content.Text: Include Unit Tests:
This configures the unit test target and creates classes for unit testing

title: Include UI test:
b
This configures the UI test target and creates classes for UI testing

inline_content.Text: Include UI test:
This configures the UI test target and creates classes for UI testing

title: Click on
Next
b
and it will ask you for a location where you want to create project directory.

inline_content.Text: Click on
Next
and it will ask you for a location where you want to create project directory.

title: Click on
Create
b
and you will see the Xcode UI with an already defined project setup. You can see some classes and Storyboard files.

inline_content.Text: Click on
Create
and you will see the Xcode UI with an already defined project setup. You can see some classes and Storyboard files.

title: This is a basic template for a Single View Application.

inline_content.Text: This is a basic template for a Single View Application.

title: At the top left of the window, check that a simulator is selected (e.g. “iPhone 6” as shown here) and then press the triangular RUN button.

inline_content.Text: At the top left of the window, check that a simulator is selected (e.g. “iPhone 6” as shown here) and then press the triangular RUN button.

title: A new application will open—Simulator (this may take some time the first time you run it and you may need to try twice if you see an error the first time). This application provides us with device simulation for created applications. It almost looks like a real device! It contains some applications like a real device. You can simulate orientations, location, shake gesture, memory warnings, In-Call Status bar, finger touch, lock, reboot, home etc.

inline_content.Text: A new application will open—Simulator (this may take some time the first time you run it and you may need to try twice if you see an error the first time). This application provides us with device simulation for created applications. It almost looks like a real device! It contains some applications like a real device. You can simulate orientations, location, shake gesture, memory warnings, In-Call Status bar, finger touch, lock, reboot, home etc.

title: You will see a plain white application because we have not made any changes to the template yet.

inline_content.Text: You will see a plain white application because we have not made any changes to the template yet.

title: So start your own. it’s a long run and there are lots of new opportunities waiting for you!

inline_content.Text: So start your own. it’s a long run and there are lots of new opportunities waiting for you!

title: If you are not sure where to go next, try out Apple’s ‘
Jump Right In
a
https://developer.apple.com/library/content/referencelibrary/GettingStarted/DevelopiOSAppsSwift/
’ tutorial. You have already performed the first few steps so are off to a head start.

inline_content.Text: If you are not sure where to go next, try out Apple’s ‘
Jump Right In
’ tutorial. You have already performed the first few steps so are off to a head start.
